S.B. 2420 enrolled on June 25, 2015 authorizes Board of Public Utilities (BPU) to limit net metering to 2.9% of the total annual kWh sold in the State by each electric power supplier during prior one year period. There is no current set cap for net metering in NJ, but the statue allows the BPU to limit net metering customers to 2.5% of the peak demand. Total netmetered systems in NJ have long surpassed the 2.5% limit, and BPU has allowed netmetering beyond this percentage.

S.B.0081 enacted on June 2015 requires the Public Utilities Commission (PUC) to open a docket by July 2015 to consider rate design and distribution cost allocation among rate classes taking in account the effects of net metering and increasing distributed energy resources. The PUC shall issue an order before March 2016, and the new rates would take effect after April 2016.

The Commission ordered the utilities to i) allow customers to assign credits from multiple host accounts to one satellite account such that sum of all the credits do not exceed 2MW per satellite account; and ii) permit the satellite accounts with less than 2MW in host account credits to be interconnected on site generation. (Case No 15-E-0267)

On Nov 25, 2015, Entergy Louisiana notified the LA Public Service Commission (PSC) that total net metered capacity in its jurisdiction had exceeded the PSC’s net metering cap of 0.5% of the retail peak load, and is no longer required by the PSC’s net metering rules to accept additional net metering applications. However, Entergy Louisiana has determined that until the PSC approves a successor net metering tariff, effective January 1, 2016, the company will continue to interconnect solar PV systems under an alternative billing arrangement, that includes a single meter with two channels - channel 1 will record the electricity consumed by the home net of any usage met by the customer’s solar system, and channel 2 will record the excess electricity produced by the system that is delivered to the grid. Customers will continue to receive credit for instantaneous self-generation and usage. The electricity consumed as recorded on channel 1 will be billed at the applicable retail rate, while any excess electricity delivered to the grid as recorded on channel 2 will be credited on the customer’s bill at Entergy Louisiana’s avoided cost adjusted for avoided line losses and daytime production. Customers who have interconnected or submitted a completed application for interconnection by December 31, 2015 will not be affected by this new billing arrangement. Entergy Louisiana has updated its net metering website to provide consumers and solar installers with additional information

In January 2016, the California Public Utilities Commission issued a ruling on its net metering success tariff. Customers on the new net metering successor tariff will have to pay an interconnection fee, estimated at $75-$150; pay all non-bypassable charges for all electricity consumed from the grid (~$0.02-0.03/kWh); and go on a time-of-use rate. The net metering successor tariff will take effect for California's three large investor-owned utilities (IOU) on July 1, 2017, or when 5% of the sum of non-coincident customer peak demand is reached for the IOU, with translates to an installed net-metered capacity of 2,409 MW for Pacific Gas and Electric, 2,240 MW for Southern California Edison, and 617 MW for San Diego Gas and Electric.

On 4/11/16, the governor signed S. 1979 into law. This bill increased the state's net metering aggregate capacity limits from 4% to 7% for private facilities and from 5% to 8% for government facilities. This bill also reduced the credit rate for net excess generation for solar facilities subject to the private net metering cap (excludes most residential systems and all government systems) from close to the retail rate to 60% of this rate beginning once the state reaches 1,600 MW in aggregate solar capacity. The bill also authorizes utilities to adopt minimum reliability charges, subject to DPU approval, and directs DOER to develop a new solar incentive program to succeed the SREC II program. The DPU adopted emergency regulations implementing S. 1979 on 5/11/16 and will replace these with final net metering regulations on 7/29/16.

H.B. 8354 enacted in June 2016 added Shared Solar facilities program, which is a separate class of virtual net metering designed to facilitate solar adoption in multifamily, campuses, multi-structure business parks, multi-tenant, or multi-owner commercial facilities, and public entities with multiple accounts. Shared Solar facility are small scale (up to 25kW) or medium scale solar facilities (up to 250 kW) that allocate bill credits to at least two and no more than fifty accounts in the same customer class and on the same or adjacent parcels of land. Public entities are not restricted by the physical location as long as the facility and the accounts are within the same municipality.

As a part of the Exelon PHI merger, the PSC initiated a grid modernization proceeding to ensure the electric distribution system in Maryland is customer centric, affordable, reliable and environmentally sustainable. The working groups in the proceeding proposed pilot program for Time Of Use (TOU) rates with changes in net metering compensation. The TOU will track on-peak and off-peak consumption and production separately, and each nets separately. In June 2018, the PSC the approved the pilot programs to be rolled out by April 2019.

As of June 2018, 700 MW of net metered systems has been installed in Maryland, reaching the 52%  of the cap of 1500 MW. Future implementation of 200 MW of community solar program will be counted against the 1500 MW cap limit.

Legislation adopted in 2018 requires Dominion to conduct a pilot program to provide compensation to any school that generates excess electricity from wind or solar on an annual basis. As of Q4 2018, Commission is reviewing the draft guidelines filed by Dominion.

The omnibus energy bill enacted in March 2018, S.B. 966, includes an enactment clause requiring utilities to investigate potential improvements to the state’s net metering and community solar programs. Each utility will hold stakeholder meetings for the development of proposed legislation. As of Q4 2018, the proceeding is ongoing.

As of Q4 2018, the DC Public Service Commission is considering rule making to add definitions for customer generator, battery, back up generation, energy storage, microgrid, smart inverter into its interconnection and net metering rules. These proposed definitions will have significant impact on eligibility of these systems as a part of net metering policy.

In 2015, the DC Public Service Commission initiated the proceeding to identify technologies and policies to modernize and increase sustainability, reliability, and efficiency. This MEDSIS initiative has continued till Q4 2018.

In May 2018, S.B. 9 signed into law made significant changes to the state's Renewable Portfolio Standard and Net Metering policies. The law ends net metering to new customers when the Residential Solar Investment Program ends or when the regulators establish the new compensation program- whichever occurs first. The existing net metering customers will be grandfathered until December 2039. Upon the closure of the existing net metering program, new customers will be able to select buy-all, sell-all option or net billing option. PURA has initiated proceeding to develop regulations of the program.
